RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR IN COMPLEX WITH SYNTHETIC LIGAND PK11195, TOPOLOGY,
RP   AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   PubMed=24653034; DOI=10.1126/science.1248725;
RA   Jaremko L., Jaremko M., Giller K., Becker S., Zweckstetter M.;
RT   "Structure of the mitochondrial translocator protein in complex with a
RT   diagnostic ligand.";
RL   Science 343:1363-1366(2014).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Can bind protoporphyrin IX and may play a role in the
CC       transport of porphyrins and heme (By similarity). Was initially
CC       identified as peripheral-type benzodiazepine receptor; can also
CC       bind isoquinoline carboxamides. Promotes the transport of
CC       cholesterol across mitochondrial membranes and may play a role in
CC       lipid metabolism (PubMed:9832438, PubMed:24814875), but its
CC       precise physiological role is controversial. According to some
CC       reports, it is not required for steroid hormone biosynthesis
CC       (PubMed:24174323, PubMed:24936060). {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24174323, ECO:0000269|PubMed:24814875,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24936060, ECO:0000269|PubMed:8114671,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:9832438}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with BZRAP1. Interacts with MOST-1. May
CC       interact with STAR. {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Mitochondrion membrane {ECO:0000250}; Multi-
CC       pass membrane protein {ECO:0000250}. Membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in liver (at protein level).
CC       Ubiquitous. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24174323,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24936060}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By dimethyl sulfoxide and diazepam.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:8125973}.
CC   -!- DISRUPTION PHENOTYPE: No obvious phenotype. Mice are viable and
CC       fertile and present only very minor changes in gonadal and adrenal
CC       steroid hormone production. testis-specific gene disruption
CC       (PubMed:24174323) does not affect testosterone production,
CC       gametogenesis and male fertility. {ECO:0000269|PubMed:24174323,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:24936060}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the TspO/BZRP family. {ECO:0000305}.

AC   Q9R1A8;
DT   23-NOV-2004, integrated into UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot.

DT   04-MAR-2015, entry version 124.
DE   RecName: Full=E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase RFWD2;
DE            EC=6.3.2.-;
DE   AltName: Full=Constitutive photomorphogenesis protein 1 homolog;
DE            Short=mCOP1;
DE   AltName: Full=RING finger and WD repeat domain protein 2;
GN   Name=Rfwd2; Synonyms=Cop1;

OC   Eukaryota; Metazoa; Chordata; Craniata; Vertebrata; Euteleostomi;

RN   [1]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA], SUBCELLULAR LOCATION, TISSUE SPECIFICITY,
RP   DOMAIN, AND MUTAGENESIS OF 113-ARG-LYS-114; 197-LYS--ARG-201;
RP   205-LYS--LYS-208; 244-LEU--LEU-246 AND 358-ARG--LYS-360.
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6J;
RX   PubMed=10395541; DOI=10.1016/S0960-9822(99)80314-5;
RA   Wang H., Kang D., Deng X.-W., Wei N.;
RT   "Evidence for functional conservation of a mammalian homologue of the
RT   light-responsive plant protein COP1.";
RL   Curr. Biol. 9:711-714(1999).
RN   [2]
RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=C57BL/6; TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;
RG   The MGC Project Team;
RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase that mediates ubiquitination
CC       and subsequent proteasomal degradation of target proteins. E3
CC       ubiquitin ligases accept ubiquitin from an E2 ubiquitin-
CC       conjugating enzyme in the form of a thioester and then directly
CC       transfers the ubiquitin to targeted substrates. Involved in JUN
CC       ubiquitination and degradation. Directly involved in p53 (TP53)
CC       ubiquitination and degradation, thereby abolishing p53-dependent
CC       transcription and apoptosis. Ubiquitinates p53 independently of
CC       MDM2 or RCHY1. Probably mediates E3 ubiquitin ligase activity by
CC       functioning as the essential RING domain subunit of larger E3
CC       complexes. In contrast, it does not constitute the catalytic RING
CC       subunit in the DCX DET1-COP1 complex that negatively regulates
CC       JUN, the ubiquitin ligase activity being mediated by RBX1 (By
CC       similarity). Involved in 14-3-3 protein sigma/SFN ubiquitination
CC       and proteasomal degradation, leading to AKT activation and
CC       promotion of cell survival. Ubiquitinates MTA1 leading to its
CC       proteasomal degradation (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Protein modification; protein ubiquitination.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer. Homodimerization is mediated by the coiled
CC       coil domain. Component of the DCX DET1-COP1 ubiquitin ligase
CC       complex at least composed of RBX1, DET1, DDB1, CUL4A and COP1.
CC       Isoform 2 does not interact with CUL4A but still binds to RBX1,
CC       suggesting that the interaction may be mediated by another cullin
CC       protein. Isoform 1 and isoform 2 interact with CUL5 but not with
CC       CUL1, CUL2 not CUL3. Interacts with bZIP transcription factors
CC       JUN, JUNB and JUND but not with FOS, ATF2 nor XBP1. Interacts with
CC       p53 (TP53) (By similarity). Interacts with COPS6; this interaction
CC       stabilizes RFWD2 through reducing its auto-ubiquitination and
CC       decelerating its turnover rate (By similarity). Interacts with
CC       SFN; this interaction leads to SFN degradation. Interacts with
CC       p53/TP53 and MTA1 (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Nucleus speckle
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10395541}. Cytoplasm
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10395541}. Note=In the nucleus, it forms
CC       nuclear speckles.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The RING finger domain, in addition to its role in
CC       ubiquitination, functions as a structural scaffold to bring two
CC       clusters of positive-charged residues within spatial proximity to
CC       mimic a bipartite nuclear localization signal (NLS).
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:10395541}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the COP1 family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 RING-type zinc finger.
CC       {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-ProRule:PRU00175}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 7 WD repeats. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00221}.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Plays a role in neurogenesis and neuronal migration.
CC       Necessary for correct formation of mitotic spindles and chromosome
CC       separation during mitosis (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds PLK1 (By similarity). Binds PAFAH1B1. Part of a
CC       complex containing PLK1, NUDC, dynein and dynactin. {ECO:0000250,
CC       ECO:0000269|PubMed:11734602}.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q61768:Kif5b; NbExp=4; IntAct=EBI-911192, EBI-776129;
CC       Q61206:Pafah1b2; NbExp=2; IntAct=EBI-911192, EBI-7445518;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cytoplasm, cytoskeleton {ECO:0000250}.
CC       Nucleus {ECO:0000250}. Note=A small proportion is nuclear, in a
CC       punctate pattern (By similarity). In a filamentous pattern
CC       adjacent to the nucleus of migrating cerebellar granule cells.
CC       Colocalizes with tubulin and dynein and with the microtubule
CC       organizing center. Distributed throughout the cytoplasm of non-
CC       migrating cells (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in fetal and adult brain, in
CC       particular in the ventricular zone of the embryonic forebrain and
CC       in the embryonic cortical plate. Highly expressed in brain cortex
CC       from new born and adult mice. Detected in the choroid plexus and
CC       in ependymal cells in embryonic brain.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:11734602, ECO:0000269|PubMed:9601647}.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: Up-regulated in silica-treated macrophages.
CC       {ECO:0000269|PubMed:7868905}.
CC   -!- PTM: Reversibly phosphorylated on serine residues during the M
CC       phase of the cell cycle. Phosphorylation on Ser-275 and Ser-327 is
CC       necessary for correct formation of mitotic spindles and chromosome
CC       separation during mitosis. Phosphorylated by PLK and other kinases
CC       (By similarity). {ECO:0000250}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the nudC family. {ECO:0000305}.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 CS domain. {ECO:0000255|PROSITE-
CC       ProRule:PRU00547}.
